section.title: Review -- Taylor Series and Approximations
section.p: In Calculus, you learn about Taylor series. The theory tells you that under certain conditions, you write a function "near" a value x as a polynomial in \Delta x:
Here, f^{(k)}(x) stands for the kth derivative (where k = 0 corresponds to the original function). If we write this in expanded notation, this looks like:
section.me: f(x+ \Delta x) = f(x) + f'(x)(\Delta x) + \frac{f"(x)}{2}(\Delta x)^2 + \frac{f"'(x)}{6}(\Delta x)^3 + \cdots + \frac{f^{(k)}(x)}{k!}(\Delta x)^k + \cdots
section.p: We call this the Taylor series around x (where x is a selected value). The "=" in this case means something about convergence (which we will naively not concern ourselves with in this course).
The value of Taylor series is that we can use finite-degree polynomials to approximate our functions:
The approximation above is called the nth order approximation.

For small n, this can be calculated by hand. For larger values of n, since there are still finitely many calculations involved, the approximation can be calculated by computers. For us, we will be interested in n = 1 or n = 2.

introduction.p: Let P(\iota) be the price (or present value) of some specific cash flows valued at a rate \iota.

task.p: Write an equation for the first order (linear) approximation for P(\iota + \Delta \iota).
Write an equation for the second order (quadratic) approximation for P(\iota + \Delta \iota).

introduction.p: Let's play with the function f(x) = e^x.

task.p: Find the Taylor series around x = 0. Since we have x = 0, just use x for \Delta x. Note that this series converges for all x.
Use your Taylor series to write down an expression for the number e, written as an infinite sum.

statement.p: Let f(x) = \sin(x). Find the first order approximation around x = 0. Since we have x = 0, just use x for \Delta x. Note that the series converges for all x.

task.p: Suppose we have a share of stock that distributes annual dividends. The first dividend is 2.50, and each dividend grows by 2% every year forever. Let P(\iota) be the price of the share (using the dividend discount model) as a function of the effective annual interest rate \iota. Write down P(\iota).
Find the first-order (linear) approximation for P(\iota + \Delta \iota).
Find the first-order (linear) approximation for \Delta P = P(\iota + \Delta \iota) - P(\iota).
Find the second-order (quadratic) approximation for P(\iota + \Delta \iota).
Find the second-order (quadratic) approximation for \Delta P.

statement.p: Let P(\iota) be the price (present value) of a level payment annuity with 10 annual payments of 125 using an effective annual interest rate of \iota. Use the calculus of actuarial symbols to find the first-order (linear) approximation for P(\iota + \Delta \iota).
What do Taylor series help us analyze for small perturbations in the interest rate? What does this tell us about interest rate risk?
